This is the closest I‚Äôm going to get to a Conan the Barbarian RPG in this day and age, please understand.

Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Odyssey is the 2nd game in the weird Assassin‚Äôs Creed RPGs and, like, the 45th game in the entire franchise. Its probably the 15th or something, I didn‚Äôt bother to look.

You play as Alexios, or Kassandra if you like being wrong. Growing up as an orphan on the island of Kephallonia, Alexios works as a mercenary, or Mithios, and does dirty or odd jobs for people so he can get money to buy bread and olive oil or whatever it was they ate back then. After taking a job from a mysterious benefactor who is obviously not a Templar precursor guy, Alexios leaves the island with his new best friend Barnabas and his ship to assassinate the Spartan General known as the Wolf, a task that leads Alexios down a conspiracy that involves not only the Greek World, but his entire family blood line. 

I have, like, 80 hours in this game on gamepass. For some reason, this one specifically clicked with me, more so than Valhalla did, and I haven‚Äôt even bothered with Origins. If you aren‚Äôt familiar with the ‚ÄúAssassin‚Äôs Creed RPGs‚Äù they‚Äôre basically The Witcher 3 clones with a bit of Genshin Impact and some other gacha game DNA. That seems to be modern Ubisoft‚Äôs bread and butter, taking formulas from other games and turning them into their own things. They did the same with the Ghost Recon franchise and a lot of Phantom Pain DNA. 

I say that, but Ubisoft isn‚Äôt doing so good right now, so oopsie poopsie on their end. 

I don‚Äôt have the same attachment to the franchise that a lot of people did, I played the series regularly until Black Flag came out and then sort of fell off, so I was also surprised when the new AC games coming out were these weird open world RPGs that took a lot of inspiration, or flat out just stole, from games like Dark Souls and The Witcher. So I never bothered with them until 2020 or so. But how actually IS Odyssey?

I like it, I mean, I like it enough that I‚Äôm going through it again. 

It‚Äôs this fun open world historical RPG that doesn‚Äôt really have the grapes to be something like Kingdom Come, but this is also the setting where Adam and Eve were cybernetic proto humans and the world used to be run by a precursor hominid race that had time travel and total god-like control over their planet. I‚Äôm never expecting historical accuracy from these games, especially with how modern day Ubisoft treats historical events and contexts as these play-Doh events where they can just change whatever as to not offend a very fringe and very select group of people. 

Odyssey is very competent in what it does. The combat system is fun, and I‚Äôm always a big fan of open world ‚ÄúChoose your own path‚Äù stealth. I was informed that Origin‚Äôs stealth damage was based on your level and you spent a lot of the time just using it as a damage buffer, I don‚Äôt know exactly how true that really is. But in Odyssey, as long as the enemy isn‚Äôt a mini boss or higher level than you, you can just stab them to death before anyone knows you‚Äôre there.
I say that, but I‚Äôve assassinated some guys that were 1 or 2 levels higher than me, so they‚Äôre fairly lenient with the stealth kills. 

The game plays out like an adventure. Alexios follows clues and info and travels across the entire Greek world, from Macedonia to Laconia and beyond. I spent a lot of time just traveling the roads and seeing new places, and there is a surprising amount of stuff to see.

Its set during the Second Peloponnesian War, which was a conflict that involved basically all of the Greek City States, choosing sides between the Delian league (Led by the Athenians) and the Peleponnesian League, led by Sparta. Its a lot more complicated than that, but the game narrows it down to just Sparta and Athens having a bit of a spat. 

Way to throw the Thesians under the bus like that, I guess. 

There‚Äôs a lot to do in this game, outside of the regular RPG combat and travel stuff. Ship combat is back, I don‚Äôt know if it was missing from previous games but here its in full effect. You can find islands to explore, jump pirates, pirate yourself if you really want to, hunt wanted pirates, stuff like that. 
Think Black Flag but with javelins and arrows instead of cannons and muskets. 

You can participate in the War itself, picking a side and helping that faction take a province in exchange for money and new equipment. Sparta and Athens don‚Äôt really hold grudges, they‚Äôll just put a bounty on your head if you screw with them too much. 
Which itself is its own thing. Unique boss characters in the form of other Misthios are roaming the world and can be fought for unique loot and experience, they‚Äôll even come looking for you if you have a bounty on your head, which can actually be intense if the bounty hunter themselves are a higher level than you. 

Its far enough back in the Assassin‚Äôs Creed Timeline that you can just find a lot of Isu and other messed up things laying around. There‚Äôs a landmark in the game that‚Äôs just the remains of a giant dead snake, I don‚Äôt think its ever explained, its just sort of there. Late game enemies include the Minotaur and Cyclopses as well as other mythological monsters rebranded as Isu war weapons. 

So what‚Äôs wrong with it? Well, Ubisoft is wrong with it. When you pause the game, there‚Äôs always these ads for the game‚Äôs in-game store, which only has items that can be bought with premium currency. There‚Äôs also pay to win items like permanent XP boosts and extra resources for crafting and upgrades as well as exchanging real money for fake ingame money. It‚Äôs such a slimy practice and I actually don‚Äôt even know why its there. Who‚Äôs looking at tacky grim reaper armor sets and thinking ‚ÄúYes, I must spend 10 actual dollars for this cosmetic item for a single player game!‚Äù 

Because of this, you‚Äôre always online. They try to wave it off with the fact that you‚Äôre being fed daily quests and other people‚Äôs taken screenshots in the pause money, but I don‚Äôt need to be online to play a single player game. This game doesn‚Äôt even have that Spy vs Spy mode that was in Brotherhood and AC3, so what‚Äôs the point of this outside of just disliking your paying customers? You‚Äôre punishing people willing to give you money to get back at people who can, will, and have gotten your game for free as well as removing the DRM that just exists to punish your actual playerbase. 

Honestly, this game would have probably made a much bigger impact if it was called something else. Like if these RPGs were called ‚ÄúAssassin‚Äôs Creed adventures‚Äù or ‚ÄúIsu Chronicles‚Äù or something. A quasi historical RPG with fantastic elements would have been a breath of fresh air from a big name publisher. 

Shit, set these games in the For Honor Universe, flesh that bad boy out a bit. You can still have the medieval/ Viking/ Greek/ Japanese aesthetic, just with a lot less rules the developers refuse to follow anyway.  

Either or, Odyssey is a good comfort game to play, you‚Äôre just going on an Ancient Greek adventure to fight evil cults and big cyborg monsters. 
I don‚Äôt actually know how the Isu make their monsters, actually, if they did, maybe those things were just something you had to deal with back then. I‚Äôm sure an Assassin‚Äôs Creed fan can tell me. 
I just honestly don‚Äôt know why these things are mainline AC games and not their own thing.

Set in ancient Greece during the Peloponnesian War, it expands the Assassin‚Äôs Creed formula into a full role-playing experience with branching dialogue, multiple endings, and deep character customization. Players control either Alexios or Kassandra, mercenaries descended from the Spartan bloodline, as they navigate political conflict, mythological mysteries, and personal discovery. The narrative explores themes of family, freedom, and destiny, with choices shaping relationships and story outcomes. The dialogue system gives players moral flexibility uncommon in earlier titles.

Gameplay emphasizes exploration and player agency. The map spans a massive recreation of Greece, filled with cities, islands, and naval routes. Combat is fast and fluid, focused on light and heavy attacks, dodging, and special abilities tied to a skill tree. This is an amendment review to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198039853258/recommended/812140/] this[/url] excellent one. Focusing on what the [i]underlying[/i] game is, what obscures it, and what the *intended* game is like.

It *seems* the game was created with the intention of refining Black Flag on top of a different map, by a very talented team. And once it was done, some *other team* came in and tried their hardest to destroy that vision. Specifically, the following are the harmful "additions" I was able to pinpoint that the "havoc team" added to the finished game, each detracting from the gameplay and the product, and being clearly orthogonal to the original game design and experience the core team was shooting for.

[olist]
[*]Levelling enemies along with the PC. This removes any sense of progress from the game.
[*]Making it so that assassination is just one of any of ordinary attacks, so is subject to HP vs Damage calculations, which is a stark contrast to all prior titles (except origins) where a dagger in the neck spelt demise (as it does in real life). Then make it so that any enemy one level higher than the player can't be 1-shotted from stealth by giving them higher HP than any damage the player can deal out (without super-powers engaged), thus completely eradicating the "assassin" part of the title.
[*]Tweak the enemy spawning so that all meaningful MOB NPCs of note spawn with 1-2 levels [i]above[/i] the player, [i]ensuring[/i] a game customer can't play as an assassin.
[*]Not leveling gear with the PC. This [i]forces[/i] the player to do constant fetch-quest and run around "picking flowers" / fetching toilet paper, 99% of the time, all throughout the game (not only in the beginning), just so they can raise the gear to the level they just "advanced" to in order to briefly be able to assassinate an NPC. And then those fetch quests level the player again, so they have to repeat this insanely pointless and boring loop infinitum.
[*]Make cost of "mandatory" upgrades scale polynomially so that the higher level the player gets, the more of the "flower picking" / Go there and kill X captains, activities they [i]have[/i] to do (forcing the player to do ever more un-fun activities the further they progress).
[/olist]

As can be seen, these 5 post-completion additions are enough to completely ruin the game. If they are removed or cancelled out, it doesn't take away [i]anything[/i] from the game. That's why I surmised these were **orthogonal** and added by a different team than that which created the game itself.

Having abandoned it after 5 hours upon original purchase half a decade ago due to the tedium, I recently tried to push my self to "experience" this title a second time around. But this time without these game-killing "bugs". After having spent 4h patching out these 5 specific issues, the game actually approached Black Flag; a fort clearing "simulator". This change revealed the game for what it was most likely intended to be, Fort clearing from Black Flag (but watered down by not having clearing forts have any persistent and regional impact) but projected onto a map of Greece. Filling that vast and **beautiful map** of Greece the graphics artists had created with some "content" meant 100x amplifying the fort-counts (copy-paste) to put [i]something[/i] in all that map space. So I'd ascribe this title to a "walking" simulator of ancient greece with optional fort clearing whenever one gets bored of walking / trotting with the slowest asthmatic horse imaginable. If one approaches it like that and wants to peak into an artistic interpretation of ancient greece, then I think it sets the expectations properly.

[list]
[*]As an adventure game... Well I think the parent review already captured it succinctly; Everyone's "out of toilet paper, please fetch them some".
[*]As an RPG. This is not one. Choices and actions have no consequence. There is no persistence. Player might as well not exist for all the "map" cares.
[*]As a show-room for a stunning map of ancient greece, it nails it.
[*]As a fort clearing title, it's about on-par with Black Flag, so *more* of *that* if that's a loop you enjoyed in the former title.
[/list]

Overall, with some patching, this surfaces the original game design vision and made me able to complete the game. I'm happy I did since the map is an absolutely stunning piece of art to have experienced. I just hope Ubi doesn't make the same mistake going forward; refraining from letting the havoc team come in once a game is done and sabotaging it like they did for this one.

If you're curious whether everything negative people say about the 'RPG' AC games is true, like I was, let me save you 80+ hours and confirm it's all true. For context, I never leave reviews. If you like a game, cool. Hate it? Cool. But I just do not understand how this game is sitting so highly rated.

I have never, NEVER, played a game so completely filled with and predicated on repetitive, mindless slop content. Every. Single. Quest is 'mistios, I've run out of toilet paper, please kill the bandits that took it' or, even worse, 'sprint around in a 100m radius circle to collect 5 leaves, I've been waiting weeks for a hero like you to come along and help'. Every quest objective is ever so slightly far away as well to feel like a complete chore to get there. This isn't just the case for the hundreds of side quests, but the main quest as well. 

Speaking of the main quest, I'd heard positive things and sadly I think those people singing the game's praises were playing a different game. To be clear there are sections of the main story I enjoyed, sections with genuinely rewarding emotional payoffs, genuinely impressive motion capture helping sell tragedy in some moments, and some great voice acting by Kassandra's voice actor. However most of what you'll be doing feels ancillary, unimportant and a complete waste of time in a game already bloated with slop content. Worst of all, I'd heard the payoff was worth it but the story just sort of... ends? The modern day aspects are also by far the worst aspects, full of characters I had genuine disdain for and, again, zero payoff.

The gameplay itself, depite the 'RPG' mechanics, is a basic and brain-dead as it's ever been in this franchise. Parkour is the biggest culprit with near enough no depth and the abilities to completely negate fall damage 10 hours into the game, and completely scale 95% of surfaces without any thought as to your path from the opening minutes of the game. Combat is animation driven slop with an incredibly low skill-ceiling and a reliance on long 'super-power' abilities that I'd honestly um and ah over whether to use. On the one hand the fight (and my misery) might end sooner, but on the other the 15 second combat animation might mean I'd be better off button mashing. If you insist on playing this game I implore you, gear yourself towards a high crit chance and crit damage build that can one-shot enemies and turn the difficulty down to easy, you'll be done a good few hours sooner.

The game is also this awkward hodge-podge of all the worst ideas from other games. Did you love the inane map-marker driven nonsense in the witcher 3? Did you also feel that while the witcher 3 was a masterpiece in some regards, the combat was a weaker aspect of the package? Good news, we've got thousands of cut and paste map markers and the combat is worse than in the witcher. Did you like the nemesis system in the LOTR Shadow franchise? Then you'll love this completely gutted, characterless mercenary system blatant copy of it. It even takes genuinely good aspects of previous games in the franchise and makes them inexplicably worse. How is the naval combat in Black Flag SO much more enjoyable, versatile and well-executed than a game by the same developers, released 4 or 5 years after it? 

My final vent is the length and the DLCs. At this stage I'm about halfway through the Fate of Atlantis. Throughout my 85ish hours with the game I've been debating whether my thoughts are it's bad game or just a mindless game that's not for me. I think I might have to give up on this torture, I'm getting more enjoyment writing about how you should please, please avoid this slop than actually pushing through the final 5 hours to at least mentally tick this game off and parcel it away in my library to never touch again.

HOWEVER, it's not all bad. The game looks gorgeous. The sync point towers provide from some great screenshot opportunities across varied and genuinely gorgeous biomes. It *seems* the game was created with the intention of refining Black Flag on top of a different map, by a very talented team. And once it was done, some *other team* came in and tried their hardest to destroy that vision. Specifically, the following are the harmful "additions" I was able to pinpoint that the "havoc team" added to the finished game, each detracting from the gameplay and the product, and being clearly orthogonal to the original game design and experience the core team was shooting for.

[olist]
[*]Levelling enemies along with the PC. This removes any sense of progress from the game.
[*]Making it so that assassination is just one of any of ordinary attacks, so is subject to HP vs Damage calculations, which is a stark contrast to all prior titles (except origins) where a dagger in the neck spelt demise (as it does in real life). Then make it so that any enemy one level higher than the player can't be 1-shotted from stealth by giving them higher HP than any damage the player can deal out (without super-powers engaged), thus completely eradicating the "assassin" part of the title.
[*]Tweak the enemy spawning so that all meaningful MOB NPCs of note spawn with 1-2 levels [i]above[/i] the player, [i]ensuring[/i] a game customer can't play as an assassin.
[*]Not leveling gear with the PC. This [i]forces[/i] the player to do constant fetch-quest and run around "picking flowers" / fetching toilet paper, 99% of the time, all throughout the game (not only in the beginning), just so they can raise the gear to the level they just "advanced" to in order to briefly be able to assassinate an NPC. And then those fetch quests level the player again, so they have to repeat this insanely pointless and boring loop infinitum.
[*]Make cost of "mandatory" upgrades scale polynomially so that the higher level the player gets, the more of the "flower picking" / Go there and kill X captains, activities they [i]have[/i] to do (forcing the player to do ever more un-fun activities the further they progress).
[/olist]

As can be seen, these 5 post-completion additions are enough to completely ruin the game. If they are removed or cancelled out, it doesn't take away [i]anything[/i] from the game. That's why I surmised these were **orthogonal** and added by a different team than that which created the game itself.

Having abandoned it after 5 hours upon original purchase half a decade ago due to the tedium, I recently tried to push my self to "experience" this title a second time around. But this time without these game-killing "bugs". After having spent 4h patching out these 5 specific issues, the game actually approached Black Flag; a fort clearing "simulator". This change revealed the game for what it was most likely intended to be, Fort clearing from Black Flag (but watered down by not having clearing forts have any persistent and regional impact) but projected onto a map of Greece. Filling that vast and **beautiful map** of Greece the graphics artists had created with some "content" meant 100x amplifying the fort-counts (copy-paste) to put [i]something[/i] in all that map space. So I'd ascribe this title to a "walking" simulator of ancient greece with optional fort clearing whenever one gets bored of walking / trotting with the slowest asthmatic horse imaginable. If one approaches it like that and wants to peak into an artistic interpretation of ancient greece, then I think it sets the expectations properly.

[list]
[*]As an adventure game... Well I think the parent review already captured it succinctly; Everyone's "out of toilet paper, please fetch them some".
[*]As an RPG. This is not one. Choices and actions have no consequence. There is no persistence. Player might as well not exist for all the "map" cares.
[*]As a show-room for a stunning map of ancient greece, it nails it.
[*]As a fort clearing title, it's about on-par with Black Flag, so *more* of *that* if that's a loop you enjoyed in the former title.
[/list]

Overall, with some patching, this surfaces the original game design vision and made me able to complete the game. I'm happy I did since the map is an absolutely stunning piece of art to have experienced. If you're curious whether everything negative people say about the 'RPG' AC games is true, like I was, let me save you 80+ hours and confirm it's all true. For context, I never leave reviews. If you like a game, cool. Hate it? Cool. But I just do not understand how this game is sitting so highly rated.

I have never, NEVER, played a game so completely filled with and predicated on repetitive, mindless slop content. Every. Single. Quest is 'mistios, I've run out of toilet paper, please kill the bandits that took it' or, even worse, 'sprint around in a 100m radius circle to collect 5 leaves, I've been waiting weeks for a hero like you to come along and help'. Every quest objective is ever so slightly far away as well to feel like a complete chore to get there. This isn't just the case for the hundreds of side quests, but the main quest as well. 

Speaking of the main quest, I'd heard positive things and sadly I think those people singing the game's praises were playing a different game. To be clear there are sections of the main story I enjoyed, sections with genuinely rewarding emotional payoffs, genuinely impressive motion capture helping sell tragedy in some moments, and some great voice acting by Kassandra's voice actor. However most of what you'll be doing feels ancillary, unimportant and a complete waste of time in a game already bloated with slop content. Worst of all, I'd heard the payoff was worth it but the story just sort of... ends? The modern day aspects are also by far the worst aspects, full of characters I had genuine disdain for and, again, zero payoff.

The gameplay itself, depite the 'RPG' mechanics, is a basic and brain-dead as it's ever been in this franchise. Parkour is the biggest culprit with near enough no depth and the abilities to completely negate fall damage 10 hours into the game, and completely scale 95% of surfaces without any thought as to your path from the opening minutes of the game. Combat is animation driven slop with an incredibly low skill-ceiling and a reliance on long 'super-power' abilities that I'd honestly um and ah over whether to use. On the one hand the fight (and my misery) might end sooner, but on the other the 15 second combat animation might mean I'd be better off button mashing. If you insist on playing this game I implore you, gear yourself towards a high crit chance and crit damage build that can one-shot enemies and turn the difficulty down to easy, you'll be done a good few hours sooner.

The game is also this awkward hodge-podge of all the worst ideas from other games. Did you love the inane map-marker driven nonsense in the witcher 3? Did you also feel that while the witcher 3 was a masterpiece in some regards, the combat was a weaker aspect of the package? Good news, we've got thousands of cut and paste map markers and the combat is worse than in the witcher. Did you like the nemesis system in the LOTR Shadow franchise? Then you'll love this completely gutted, characterless mercenary system blatant copy of it. It even takes genuinely good aspects of previous games in the franchise and makes them inexplicably worse. How is the naval combat in Black Flag SO much more enjoyable, versatile and well-executed than a game by the same developers, released 4 or 5 years after it? 

My final vent is the length and the DLCs. At this stage I'm about halfway through the Fate of Atlantis. Throughout my 85ish hours with the game I've been debating whether my thoughts are it's bad game or just a mindless game that's not for me. I was thinking the latter held true but this game is so intent on showing more and more hours of pointlessness down my throat that I simply can't picture anyone who'd enjoy the content on offer stretched over this length. Genuinely, I want to meet them, the same way I'd be interested to discuss with a serial killer why they are the way they are so I can just understand how their brain works more than anything. I thought approx 7.5hrs ago that I was finally coming to end with this game but had the awful realisation this final DLC looked a little large. So I googled. 15 hours long. I'm trying. Seriously, I'm trying to get through it. But the negatives of the main game are even sharper here with even less payoff. I think I might have to give up on this torture, I'm getting more enjoyment writing about how you should please, please avoid this slop than actually pushing through the final 5 hours to at least mentally tick this game off and parcel it away in my library to never touch again.

HOWEVER, it's not all bad. The game looks gorgeous. The sync point towers provide from some great screenshot opportunities across varied and genuinely gorgeous biomes. It feels like a success in being an 'odyssey' in this respect. It runs surprisingly well as well. I've got a strong rig but I was genuinely surprised to see I could push 1440p ultrawide at 100fps (with dips to 80ish in city areas). Additionally, there was a period of about 10hrs where I just roamed the Aegean, landing on new islands, completing quest chains and indiscriminately stabbing my way through Greece. This felt like the game I imagined it could be. Well put together, contained, gorgeous, a genuine sense of discovery. Were all these positive worth the slog of the remainder of the game though? No. Not even slightly. This game is a case study in how to create a gorgeous, soulless time sink that has no regard for the intelligence or time of players and I'm genuinely baffled as to how this half-baked RPG nonsense the franchise has turned to hasn't completely killed this tired franchise that I (for better or worse) spent so much time with as a kid.

By all means give it a go, but if you aren't hooked within 2hrs, please please refund this. It doesn't get better, it just gets longer.
